verses.text: Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, you rulers of the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: This verse calls leaders to humility and attentive wisdom, similar to how Proverbs emphasizes the foundation of true authority.

verses.text: Give ear, you who rule multitudes and take pride in many nations.
verses.comment: God holds rulers accountable, echoing the theme of divine judgment on leaders in Psalm 82.

verses.text: Because your authority was given by the Lord, and your power by the Most High, who will examine your works and search out your intentions.
verses.comment: Human authority is only temporary and stems from God's sovereignty. God will judge not just outward actions but even the secret motivations of the heart.

verses.text: For though you were ministers of his kingdom, you did not judge uprightly, nor keep the law, nor walk according to God’s will.
verses.comment: Echoes the call for just judgment by earthly rulers, ultimately fulfilled by the future Messiah who judges righteously.

verses.text: He will come upon you terribly and swiftly, because judgment is severe on those in high position.
verses.comment: Judgment is stricter for spiritual leaders and rulers (cf. Luke 12:48: 'To whom much is given, much is required').

verses.text: For the least may be forgiven in mercy, but the mighty will be powerfully tested.
verses.comment: Those entrusted with more responsibility receive stricter judgment, a principle Jesus reiterates in the Gospels.

verses.text: For the Lord of all will not show partiality, nor will he fear greatness; for he made both great and small, and cares for all alike.
verses.comment: God's impartial justice is highlighted, later reaffirmed by Peter in Acts 10:34-35 ('God shows no partiality').

verses.text: But for the mighty, a severe examination awaits.
verses.comment: A reminder that accountability is higher for those in authority in both Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: To you, therefore, O monarchs, my words are directed, so that you may learn wisdom and not fall away.
verses.comment: Wisdom is the sure foundation for those in authority to stay faithful.

verses.text: For those who keep the holy things in holiness will be made holy, and those who are taught them will find a defense.
verses.comment: The principle of sanctification is connected to faithfulness to holy teachings, foreshadowing New Testament callings to holiness.

verses.text: Desire my words; yearn for them, and you will be instructed.
verses.comment: A call to love wisdom mirrors the Psalmist’s zeal for God’s law.

verses.text: Wisdom is radiant and unfading, easily perceived by those who love her, and found by those who seek her.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s accessibility echoes Jesus’ promise: 'Seek, and you will find.' In Christian reading, wisdom is ultimately fulfilled in Christ, 'the wisdom of God.'

verses.text: She hastens to make herself known to those who desire her.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s eagerness highlights God’s initiative in drawing seekers to Himself.

verses.text: He who rises early to seek her will have no difficulty, for he will find her sitting at his door.
verses.comment: Encourages early and diligent pursuit of wisdom as the beginning of understanding.

verses.text: To meditate on her is perfect understanding, and he who stays awake for her will soon be free from care.
verses.comment: Meditation on wisdom is equated with spiritual peace—the spiritual practice of dwelling on God’s instruction is a classic path to freedom from anxiety.

verses.text: For she herself goes about seeking those worthy of her, and graciously appears to them on their paths, and meets them in every thought.
verses.comment: Wisdom is portrayed as more than abstract: she actively seeks out the worthy, a strong hint of God’s grace drawing people to Himself.

verses.text: The beginning of desire for wisdom is a sincere will for instruction; concern for instruction is love for her;
verses.comment: True wisdom begins in a heart open to receiving teaching, reflecting the 'fear of the Lord' as the start of wisdom.

verses.text: Love for her means keeping her laws; obeying her laws is assurance of immortality;
verses.comment: The connection between love of wisdom, keeping commandments, and immortality points to perfection through obedience—a key scriptural theme later fulfilled in Christ’s obedience (see Matthew 19).

verses.text: And immortality brings one near to God;
verses.comment: Eternal life is found in union with God, a central Christian hope (cf. John 17:3).

verses.text: Thus, the desire for wisdom leads to a kingdom.
verses.comment: Those who seek wisdom are promised the kingdom—an echo of 'seek first the kingdom of God.' The verse suggests God’s reign is tied to wisdom and righteous desire.

verses.text: So if you delight in thrones and scepters, O rulers of the peoples, honor wisdom, so that you may reign forever.
verses.comment: Eternal reign is granted not by mere power, but through the pursuit of wisdom—a foreshadowing of Christ’s eternal kingship and the saints' participation in His reign.

verses.text: I will tell you what wisdom is and how she came to be. I will not hide mysteries from you, but will trace her out from the beginning of creation, and make knowledge of her clear; I will not pass by the truth.
verses.comment: Introduces a deep revelation about wisdom’s origin, echoing Proverbs 8’s personification and pre-existence of wisdom—seen as a foreshadowing of Christ, the eternal Word (cf. John 1:1-3).

verses.text: Nor will I travel in the company of consuming envy, for envy has nothing in common with wisdom.
verses.comment: Highlights a moral difference between wisdom and envy—an echo of James's contrast between heavenly wisdom and bitter jealousy.

verses.text: A multitude of the wise is the salvation of the world, and a sensible king is the stability of a people.
verses.comment: Scripture teaches that salvation and peace come through wise leaders—a principle manifested most fully in Christ as the King who saves His people through perfect wisdom.

verses.text: Therefore accept instruction from my words, and you will profit.
verses.comment: The book ends this chapter by urging the listener to receive wisdom’s instruction for true profit—echoing Jesus’s teaching that true treasure is found in the kingdom, not in worldly riches.
